user_error_text: I experience No display / No signal and cannot see BIOS or Windows
symptoms: Monitor shows 'No Signal'; black screen; no BIOS/POST display
cause: Loose cables, wrong input, GPU not seated, failed GPU/monitor
step_1: Ensure monitor power and input source are correct; check cables are fully inserted.
step_2: Try a different cable and different monitor input (HDMI/DP/VGA).
step_3: If desktop: reseat GPU and check PCI-E power cables; test with onboard video if available.
step_4: Reset CMOS/BIOS settings to defaults to clear misconfigurations.
step_5: Test GPU in another system or try a known-good GPU to isolate hardware.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: GPU: No display / No signal - nvlddmkm driver stopped responding and has recovered

user_error_text: Screen flickering started after a driver update
symptoms: Screen flickers intermittently or during certain apps; visible tearing
cause: Driver issues, refresh rate mismatch, faulty cable or failing panel
step_1: Update or reinstall display drivers from GPU vendor website.
step_2: Check and set correct refresh rate in Display Settings; match monitor spec.
step_3: Try a different cable (use high-quality HDMI/DP) and port.
step_4: Disable hardware acceleration in apps that flicker (e.g., browsers).
step_5: If flicker persists on multiple monitors, consider panel or GPU replacement.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: GPU: Screen flickering - nvlddmkm driver stopped responding and has recovered

user_error_text: GPU driver crash and troubleshooting suggests display adapter issue
symptoms: Display driver stopped responding; application or system recovery messages
cause: Driver corruption, overheating, or incompatible driver
step_1: Update GPU drivers to the latest WHQL release from vendor site.
step_2: Use DDU in Safe Mode to remove old drivers and perform a clean install.
step_3: Monitor GPU temps and ensure adequate cooling; clean fans and heatsink.
step_4: Reduce overclocking or revert to default GPU clocks.
step_5: If crashes continue, test GPU in another system or RMA if under warranty.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Graphics: GPU driver crash - DXGI error on present

user_error_text: Monitor not recognized — my monitor is blank after powering on
symptoms: Monitor not listed in Display Settings; EDID not read; generic PnP monitor shown
cause: Faulty cable, EDID read failure, or monitor OSD/input issue
step_1: Power cycle the monitor and reconnect cables; try a different cable.
step_2: Check Device Manager for 'Generic PnP Monitor' and update the monitor driver manually.
step_3: Try connecting monitor to another PC to verify monitor functionality.
step_4: Reset monitor to factory settings via OSD menu.
step_5: If EDID is broken, use a different monitor or contact manufacturer for firmware update.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Kernel-PnP: Monitor not recognized - device not migrated

user_error_text: Artifacts / graphical corruption after waking from sleep
symptoms: Strange colored blocks, lines, or visual glitches on screen
cause: Failing GPU/VRAM, driver bug, or overheating
step_1: Lower graphics settings and stop GPU-intensive tasks immediately.
step_2: Update or roll back GPU drivers to known stable version.
step_3: Check GPU temperature and power delivery; reseat GPU and cables.
step_4: Run GPU stress test briefly to reproduce and diagnose; stop if artifacts appear.
step_5: Replace GPU if artifacts persist across systems; recover data and backup.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Display: Artifacts / graphical corruption - no adapter output detected

user_error_text: Artifacts / graphical corruption and troubleshooting suggests display adapter issue
symptoms: Strange colored blocks, lines, or visual glitches on screen
cause: Failing GPU/VRAM, driver bug, or overheating
step_1: Lower graphics settings and stop GPU-intensive tasks immediately.
step_2: Update or roll back GPU drivers to known stable version.
step_3: Check GPU temperature and power delivery; reseat GPU and cables.
step_4: Run GPU stress test briefly to reproduce and diagnose; stop if artifacts appear.
step_5: Replace GPU if artifacts persist across systems; recover data and backup.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Kernel-PnP: Artifacts / graphical corruption - device not migrated

user_error_text: Black screen after login and troubleshooting suggests display adapter issue
symptoms: After entering credentials, screen goes black while OS loads
cause: Explorer.exe issues, corrupted profile, or driver problems
step_1: Press Ctrl+Alt+Del and open Task Manager; try to start explorer.exe manually.
step_2: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall recent drivers or updates.
step_3: Create a new user profile to test if profile corruption causes black screen.
step_4: Run SFC and DISM from Command Prompt to repair system files: sfc /scannow; DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
step_5: If unresolved, perform System Restore to earlier point.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: GPU: Black screen after login - nvlddmkm driver stopped responding and has recovered

user_error_text: Wrong resolution / scaling issues started after a driver update
symptoms: Display is blurry, UI elements oversized or undersized, apps not scaled correctly
cause: Incorrect resolution, DPI scaling, or display driver mismatch
step_1: Set the display to native resolution via Display Settings.
step_2: Adjust scaling to 100% or recommended setting and sign out to apply.
step_3: Update GPU/display drivers and check monitor drivers for EDID issues.
step_4: For multi-monitor setups, set scaling per-monitor and use recommended resolutions.
step_5: If apps look blurry, use compatibility settings (Right-click app → Properties → Compatibility → Change high DPI settings).
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Monitor: Wrong resolution / scaling issues - EDID read failed

user_error_text: I experience Multiple monitors not detected and cannot see BIOS or Windows
symptoms: Secondary monitor not detected or shows 'No Signal'
cause: Output port issue, cable, GPU limitations or disabled display in settings
step_1: Ensure GPU/PC supports the number of monitors and check ports/cables.
step_2: Use Display Settings → Detect to force Windows to scan for monitors.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and check monitor OSD input selection.
step_4: Try different port combinations (DP + HDMI) and verify monitor power.
step_5: Test each monitor independently to isolate problematic monitor or cable.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Monitor: Multiple monitors not detected - EDID read failed

user_error_text: My system shows FPS drop / stuttering in games and reboots sometimes
symptoms: Sudden drops in FPS, stutter during gameplay, inconsistent frame times
cause: Driver issues, background processes, thermal throttling, or v-sync problems
step_1: Close background apps and set power plan to High Performance.
step_2: Update GPU drivers and set game to use discrete GPU if laptop.
step_3: Lower in-game settings and disable background overlays (Discord/Steam overlay).
step_4: Check temps for thermal throttling and improve cooling.
step_5: If issue persists, test with older driver versions or clean install using DDU.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Graphics: FPS drop / stuttering in games - DXGI error on present

step_1: Close background apps and set power plan to High Performance.
step_2: Update GPU drivers and set game to use discrete GPU if laptop.
step_3: Lower in-game settings and disable background overlays (Discord/Steam overlay).
step_4: Check temps for thermal throttling and improve cooling.
step_5: If issue persists, test with older driver versions or clean install using DDU.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Display: FPS drop / stuttering in games - no adapter output detected

user_error_text: Color / brightness incorrect and troubleshooting suggests display adapter issue
symptoms: Colors look washed out or too dark; brightness controls not working
cause: Incorrect color profile, monitor settings, or driver/firmware issue
step_1: Reset monitor color settings to factory defaults and check OSD brightness.
step_2: Install or select correct color profile (ICC) for the monitor in Color Management.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and check for monitor firmware updates.
step_4: Test different display cables (DP/HDMI) and ports.
step_5: If external monitor, test on another computer to rule out monitor fault.
verification: Display works normally at expected resolution/refresh rate with stable graphics during use.
log_snippet: Graphics: Color / brightness incorrect - DXGI error on present
